example-learning-objective.text: Prose we want to show up in the lesson.
example-learning-objective.assessment-rec: author notes about how it might be assessed.

cat-v-quant-def.text: Explain the difference between Categorical and Quantitative data, recognizing that Quantitative data measures an amount while Categorical data is used to qualify.

cat-v-quant-variable.text: Identify whether a variable in a dataset is Categorical or Quantitative by considering whether the data tells us "what kind?" or "how much?".

pros-cons-bar-pie.text: Recognize that while pie charts and bar charts both display the counts of categorical data, consideration should be given to which is a more useful display for a given situation.

interpret-bar.text: Interpret bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-pie.text: Interpret pie charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-stacked-bar.text: Interpret stacked bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

interpret-multi-bar.text: Interpret multi-bar charts to answer statistical questions about a dataset.

describe-data-cycle.text: Describe the four parts of the Data Cycle, including: (1) ask questions, (2) consider the data, (3) analyze the data, and (4) interpret the data.

develop-statistical-question.text: Develop a statistical research question about a real-world dataset.

stat-inference.text: Explain how statistical inference uses information from a sample (e.g., probability) to draw conclusions about the larger population from which the sample was taken.

sample-size.text: Describe the role of sample size, recognizing that larger samples generally yield better estimates of what's true for a population.

random-sample-bias.text: Describe how random sampling can help us avoid bias in our analysis.

sensible-grouped-samples.text: Identify sensible grouped samples for a dataset.

infographic-ratios.text: Assess whether various infographics effectively incorporate ratios and proportions by considering the infographic's impact.

infographic-stereotypes.text: Avoid stereotyping when creating an infographic in order to help viewers relate to and understand the topic.

rows-and-columns.text: Identify the specific Rows and Columns needed to answer various questions.

describe-dataset.text: Describe a dataset by discussing its source, structure, and relevance.

define-subsets.text: Define tables of differently sized subsets from a dataset in Pyret.

explanatory-response.text: Differentiate between an explanatory variable and a response variable, recognizing that the response variable (plotted on the y-axis) responds to the explanatory variable (plotted on the x-axis).

scatter-plots-by-hand.text: Make scatter plots by hand given a list of (x,y) pairs.

trends-in-scatter-plots.text: Identify possible trends in scatter-plots by exploring relationships between columns.

unusual-observations.text: Understand that unusual observations are always worth thinking about: sometimes they are random, sometimes they provide deeper insight, and sometimes are the points we are looking for.

visual-cues.text: Explain how visual cues can enhance a display by making it more meaningful, accessible, or exciting.

order-matters.text: Understand that composing table operations in a particular order (build, filter, sort) is required to avoid crashing the program or producing nonsensical results.

diagram-composition.text: Diagram function composition to make sense of the order in which table operations must be performed.

compose-table-ops.text: Compose table operations to conduct more sophisticated analyses.

make-dot-plots.text: Make dot plots by hand to display the frequency of values in quantitative data.

dot-plot-features.text: Describe the distribution of data in a dot plot by identifying peaks, clusters, gaps, outliers, and typicality.

variability-define.text: Define the variability of a categorical dataset as how different or alike data points are.

variability-describe.text: Describe the variability of a data in a dot plot, recognizing that increased variability results in a wider spread while decreased variability results in a more narrow spread.

dot-plot-v-histogram.text: Compare and contrast dot plots and histograms, recognizing that: (1) both display the frequency and distribution of quantitative data, and (2) dot plots display the frequency of individual values while histograms display the frequency of groups of values.
dot-plot-v-histogram.assessment-rec: match dot plots and histograms; evaluate merits of each.

best-measure-of-center.text: Determine which measure of center – mean, median, or mode – best summarizes a dataset.

histograms-and-measures-of-center.text: Draw conclusions about the mean, median, and mode of a dataset by represented by a histogram.

peaks-clusters-gaps.text: Describe the distribution of data in a histogram by identifying peaks, clusters, gaps, and outliers in histograms.

histogram-skew-or-symmetric.text: Identify a histogram's shape as skewed right, skewed left, or symmetric.

bar-chart-v-histogram.text: Understand that bar charts display the frequency of categorical data while histograms show the frequency and distribution of quantitative data.
bar-chart-v-histogram.assessment-rec: use enrollment-by-college question from Whitaker & Jacobbe, 2017.

histogram-shape.text: Use a histogram's shape to draw conclusions about quantitative data.
histogram-shape.assessment-rec: update Joy's What Shape Makes Sense, make it required.

choosing-bin-size.text: Recognize that changing a histogram's bin size impacts the histogram's shape and can affect what we learn about the distribution of the data.

make-histograms.text: Make histograms by hand and in @proglang to represent a quantitative dataset.

histogram-center-spread.text: Make claims about the center and spread of a histogram.

histogram-variability.text: Assess the level of variability displayed by a histogram.

histograms-by-hand.text: Make histograms by hand to represent a quantitative dataset.

boxplot-create.text: Compute the 5-number summary and draw the box plot for a given dataset.
boxplot-create.assessment-rec: Give students a dataset, have them calculate the 5-number summary and draw a box plot.

spread-transfer.text: Compare and contrast information displayed in a box plot and a histogram, identifying that box plots have variable intervals and histograms have fixed bins.
spread-transfer.assessment-rec: Have students match box plots to histograms.

stdev-understand.text: Use standard deviation to make judgments about data, and understand the role it plays in those judgements.
stdev-understand.assessment-rec: Compare two datasets, their means and stdevs, and a conclusion that ignores the stdev. Ask students why the conclusion is wrong.

stdev-calc.text: Calculate the standard deviation of a dataset.
stdev-calc.assessment-rec: Give students a dataset, have them calculate the stdev.

form.text: Determine whether a scatter plot's form seems to be linear, nonlinear, or have no relationship at all.

direction.text: Determine whether a scatter plot's direction is positive, negative, or neither.

strength.text: Determine whether a scatter plot's strength is strong (knowing the x-value of a point gives us a good idea of what the y-value) or weak (knowing the x-value tells us little about y-value).

linear-regression.text: Determine line-of-best-fit using linear regression, use regression lines to make predictions, and use model-fit statistics to assess the reliability of those predictions.

threats-demonstrate.text: Demonstrate how various threats to validity can impact the validity of conclusions drawn when research is conducted.

misuse-identify.text: Identify the misuse of statistics in a variety of scenarios and explain how it can result in distortion of the data and false claims.

outlier-impact.text: Recognize that the decision of whether or not to keep an outlier can have a profound impact on validity.

when-subsets-make-sense.text: Understand that when there is variability between subsets in a column of data it might not make sense to look for trends in the whole.

use-contracts.text: Use contracts to write expressions that will produce one-variable visualizations in @proglang (pie charts, bar charts, histograms, and box plots).

read-contracts.text: Make sense of functions in @proglang by interpreting their contracts.

table-build-column.text: Add a column to a table.
table-build-column.assessment-rec: Give students a starter-file with a table and have them add a column

table-filter.text: Filter a table using a Boolean-producing function.
table-filter.assessment-rec: Give students a starter-file with a table and have them filter it.

random-sample-pyret.text: Use Pyret to generate differently sized random samples from a dataset.

measures-of-center-proglang.text: Compute measures of center including mean, median and mode(s) of a dataset in @proglang.

measures-of-spread-proglang.text: Compute measures of spread of a dataset including range and IQR in @proglang.

histograms-proglang.text: Make histograms in proglang to represent a quantitative dataset.

categorical-visualizations-proglang.text: Create categorical visualizations from a single column of a dataset in @proglang (i.e. pie charts, bar charts).

compound-categorical-visualizations-prog.text: Create categorical visualizations from two columns of a dataset in @proglang (i.e. multi-bar charts, stacked-bar charts).

advanced-display-pyret.text: Create an advanced display in Pyret to present information about an additional variable that would otherwise not be considered.

develop-survey.text: Develop a survey that avoids data-hygiene problems such as missing data, inconsistent types, inconsistent units, and inconsistent naming.

response-validation.text: Use response validation in Google Forms, including Required Questions, Question Format, Descriptive Instructions, and Specify Parameters.

id-hygiene-probs.text: Identify different data hygiene problems that can compromise analysis (i.e., variations in spelling and capitalization, typos, etc).

import-data.text: Import data from a Google Sheet into @proglang.

five-num-summary-compute.text: Compute the values in the five-number summary for a dataset (minimum, Q1, median, Q3, and maximum).

five-num-summary-interpret.text: Interpret the values in the five-number summary for a dataset (minimum, Q1, median, Q3, and maximum).

box-plot-create.text: Create a box plot from a five-number summary.

box-plot-interpret.text: Interpret a box plot to answer questions about a dataset and its spread.

box-plot-shape.text: Describe box plot shape including skew, symmetry and potential outliers.

box-plot-histogram.text: Recognize the shape of various distributions, and identify that shape in box plots and histograms.

direction-strength.text: Identify the apparent direction and strength of a relationship from a scatter plot.

r-value.text: Recognize that r-value represents the relationship between an independent and dependent variable; it ranges from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

predict-values.text: Use a predictor function to predict values that are not included in the dataset.

write-about-lr.text: Summarize what can be learned about a dataset from the results of linear regression, using proper statistical terminology.
